awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Undergraduate Research Groups in the CSU Alliance for PUMP: Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring toward PhDs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on increasing the participation of underrepresented students in PhD programs in the mathematical sciences. These students include undergraduates currently at a California State University (CSU) which are ethnic minorities, first-generation college, or financially disadvantaged. This will be accomplished by a CSU Alliance including all 23 campuses, which provides a robust recruitment process, training for faculty on how to be a strong mentor, and frequent assessment. Students are equipped with the tools to be successful in doctoral programs through high-quality, personalized activities. PUMP has already had tremendous success on southern CSU campuses and is now being extended to include northern campuses as well.

The activities for this project include (a) an orientation workshop for faculty geared to maximize the success of mentoring students from underrepresented groups; (b) at least one year of undergraduate research projects for junior and senior math majors; and (c) a PUMP symposium where the undergraduates will present talks on their research. The PUMP undergraduate research group (URG) is structured so that students master the mathematical content while developing the ability to go from general course work to independent work and research. The program requires that topics for the URGs, while accessible to students, make meaningful contributions to the mathematical sciences, allowing the faculty from institutions with limited research opportunities to keep current and active in their fields. This project shall contribute to increasing the quantity, quality, and diversity of the mathematical sciences workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

por.por_cntn:
The CSU Alliance for PUMP (Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring toward PhDs) seeks to to identify mathematical talent among minority students, women, and first-generation college students in the California State Universities and to strengthen the preparation of participating undergraduates to successfully pursue advanced degrees (PhDs) in a research institution.

 

The major goals of this grant supporting PUMP include: (1) forming a new alliance among all 23 campuses of the California State University (CSU) system which will extend the PUMP program, (2) building a community of mentors that will work on creating welcoming and inclusive departments and on institutionalizing the values of mentoring, and (3) increasing the number of students from historically underrepresented groups (HUGs) who enter doctoral programs in the mathematical sciences.

 

With this grant, the PUMP Alliance was extended to all CSU campuses for the first time. The forming of the extended PUMP Alliance began with a network of liaisons and department chairs at each campus; each liaison advertised mentoring and research opportunities to their fellow math faculty members as well as undergraduates. We were able to recruit 25 PUMP faculty mentors across 14 CSU campuses, 6 Northern and 8 Southern (Cal Poly Pomona, Cal State LA, Channel Islands, East Bay, Fresno, Fullerton, Humboldt, Long Beach, Northridge, San Bernardino, San Diego State, San Francisco State, San Jos? State, Stanislaus). Each participating faculty member mentored two (sometimes one or three) undergraduate math majors in a year-long research project, beginning with a faculty orientation on successful mentoring practices and culminating in a symposium where students presented their research. A total of 51 students were supported by PUMP through this grant, nearly all from groups historically underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. At least 10 of these students have already been accepted into well-respected PhD programs like Purdue, Georgia Tech, Indiana University at Bloomington, Colorado at Boulder, and the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, among others. An additional 8 PUMP students entered Master?s programs in the mathematical sciences, and 17 others indicated they intend on applying to a graduate program in the mathematical sciences when they finish their undergraduate degrees. For CSU students, a Master's degree often acts as a bridge to a PhD program.

 

The intellectual merit lies in the engagement with open problems from a range of sub-disciplines in the mathematical sciences and some interdisciplinary fields. Supporting faculty research and best practices in mentoring undergraduate research, particularly among diverse populations, is the key to success. The topics represented include Fractal Geometry, Analysis, Quantum Mechanics, Algebraic Topology, Applied Mathematics, Data Analysis and Predictive Modeling, Math Biology, Graph Theory, Number Theory, Knot Theory, and Mathematics Education. Our PUMP research groups have produced 6 articles (4 appeared, 1 accepted, 1 in review) with several others in preparation. Additionally, our students have given many talks and poster presentations at local, regional, and national conferences, to disseminate their results.

 

The broader impacts PUMP provides mostly come from the funded research opportunities to students from groups which are historically underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. Many of these students have financial constraints and are first-generation college students, both of which can be obstacles to successfully applying for and entering graduate school. Through mentoring and financial support, PUMP has increased the number of HUGs students entering PhD programs. Those students who participated in PUMP (including those who ended up with an advanced degree and/or a career in the mathematical sciences) are likely to have a long lasting, positive impact for their family and community. Moreover, their successes can inspire future generations of mathematicians from HUGs. The collaboration among the CSUs themselves and with the University of Utah Pre-REU demonstrates the impact beyond the program, and in particular, the PUMP model has potential for success in other university systems.


Last Modified: 10/26/2023
Modified by: Jordan Schettler
